title: Designate optional sections in the codeowners file
description:
## Problem to solve

With [code owners sections](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/code_owners.html#code-owners-sections), all code owner rules must be enforced or none. This means that if there are important compliance rules that must be enforced, every rule must be enforced. This means another team that simply wants to be notified and added as optional approvers of relevant merge requests must forgo using code owners or become a required approver.

Currently we handle the requiring of code owner approval through the protected branch POST (create) endpoint [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/controllers/projects/protected_refs_controller.rb#L17).

## Proposal

Specify optional rules in the code owners file</summary>

Use declarative nomenclature before a rule to mark it as optional, for example `^`.

Foe example in the following file, the `Database` section would not be enforced as it has been denoted as optional

```
[Documentation]
ee/docs    @gl-docs
docs       @gl-docs

^[Database]
README.md  @gl-database
model/db   @gl-database
```
**For duplicated sections and rules, the most restrictive should always win.**

<details>
<summary>Prior proposal (for ref only): Allow users to select a code owners section as an approval rule for newly protected branches.</summary>

![image](/uploads/97d77e1f33c7bcc8db2e713963c529e6/image.png)

Code owners dropdown
![image](/uploads/9ccc4da732bb95fb888c33895f924ddf/image.png)

Acceptance Criteria:

- We can create a new protected branch with selected sections
- When we create a new protected branch, we sync the approval rules

</details>

**Note** Make sure to use [`Gitlab::CodeOwners.sections`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/48898) to fetch available sections

## Feature flag

`optional_code_owners_sections`

### Release notes

[Code owners sections](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/code_owners.html#code-owners-sections) allow each team to configure their own code owners entries independently. The section rules may be used for shared paths so that multiple teams can be added as reviewers. However, all code owner sections must be enforced or none. For example, if there are important compliance rules that must be enforced, every rule must be enforced. This means another team that simply wants to be added as optional approvers of relevant merge requests must forgo using code owners or become a required approver.

GitLab 13.8 introduces the ability to designate optional sections in your code owners file. Simply prepend the section name with the caret `^` character and the section will be treated as optional. This means, related change through merge requests will not require approval from designated owners. With optional sections you may continue to designate responsible parties for various parts of the code while providing a more relaxed policy for parts of your project that may be updated often but don't require stringent reviews.

epic.title: Support selecting code owners sections as required approval rule

title: Update UI copy for merge request tab empty state
description:
### Problem to solve

The Compliance Dashboard empty state for merge requests does not provide enough contextual information to understand how this page on the dashboard becomes populated.

Initiated by [this discussion in Slack](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CN7C8029H/p1596035724143300):

> Austin Regnery: Why is it that despite there being 20 MR related to this group, nothing shows up for me in the Compliance Dashboard? 

> Aishwarya: I think we show only merged MRs, but let me confirm quick in the codebase

> Matt Gonzales: That's correct :slightly_smiling_face: Most recent, merged MRs; 1 per project

> Austin Regnery: Seeing a really easy opportunity to make that clear to novices like me. I am going to open an issue to propose clearer UI copy on empty state :slightly_smiling_face:

**Conditional logic:** Shows only the most recently merged Merge Request; max 1 per project

|Current Empty State|Proposed Change ([see comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232989#note_388343196))|
|---|---|
|![image](/uploads/375423f3c400175149f29b3b23696575/image.png)|![image](/uploads/68eb09f6dda54822aab446f654e1b69d/image.png)|

title: Update Gitlab::CodeOwners to use the database version of CODEOWNERS
description:
Depending on how we approach this, we may want to 'databasify' all the CODEOWNER files at once, or 'databasify' them when they are touched. Regardless of the approach we need to switch some of the accessing of Gitlab::CodeOwners to be through the database rather than through the file.

Acceptance Criteria:

- We access the CODEOWNER information through the database
- There is a strategy in place to migrate all the CODEOWNER files to the database

epic.title: Represent code owners in the database

title: Update the code owner tables when the CODEOWNERS file changes
description:
Having two representations of the same data, one in the file, and one in the database we need to ensure that these are always the same.

We need to continue work on this story: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232981 and extend it so that we also update the database tables with the changed data.

Acceptance Criteria:

- The code owners database representation always matches the files

epic.title: Represent code owners in the database

title: Create database tables to represent CODEOWNERS
description:
A benefit of creating a database representation is, rather than accessing the file through Gitaly each time, we can go through the database which is quicker.

This issue is simply creating the database tables that will be used to represent the CODEOWNERS file.

Acceptance Criteria:

- A CODEOWNERS file can be represented in the database
- Basic classes with the associated models

epic.title: Represent code owners in the database

title: Scan commits for changes to CODEOWNERS
description:
When there is a new commit on a branch, we need to check if one of the files that has been updated is the `CODEOWNERS` file. If this file has been updated, then we need to sync the code owner approval rules for all the merge requests that have this as a target branch.

Acceptance Criteria:

- When a change is made to any of the three potential code owner files, the approval rules are resynced.

epic.title: Represent code owners in the database

title: "Include merge request description" or any custom merge commit message not working with Merge Trains enabled
description:
### Summary

In a configuration with "Enable merge trains and pipelines for merged results" the option "Include merge request description" does not add the description to the commit message.

### Steps to reproduce

Setup a project with "Enable merge trains and pipelines for merged results", open a Merge Request and set "Include merge request description". See commit history.

### Example Project
https://gitlab.com/till.steinbach/new-project/

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
Commit message does not contain merge request description

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
Commit message should contain merge request description


### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

title: Cache composer.json in database and make it available to frontend
description:
In order for the frontend to display composer package related metadata, it needs to read the contents of `composer.json` file.

To achieve this we need to save the `composer.json` file to the composer package metadata and then return it as part of the api.

title: Add created_at to job webhooks
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Add "created_at" field to job webhook, to improve consistency with the API response for jobs.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

### User experience goal

Improved data consistency across job API and job webhooks.

### Proposal

Add the "created_at" time field to the job webhook return - it already exists in the job API responses, so presumably just put it into the job webhook using same timestamp format and value.

### Further details

Right now, if we want to know 100% when a job was created based on a webhook we receive, we need to call the gitlab API to get this data, which essentially negates a lot of the benefits we get with webhooks. 

### Permissions and Security

No changes to security anticipated, just an update to webhook data.

### Documentation

title: Update variables of an existing .gitlab-ci.yml
description:
In [Write variables to a new .gitlab-ci.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229976), we added the ability to write a few supported SAST variables to a new .gitlab-ci.yml file.

As a next iteration, we need to support updating supported SAST variables in an existing .gitlab-ci.yml file. This should also account for removing supported SAST variables that are no longer set.

### Implementation Plan

*  Add logic for updating a .gitlab-ci.yml
*  Add specs

epic.title: SAST Config UI Page - Basic SAST Wide Settings

title: [Step 4] Update UsageData to include the new counters
description:
After implementing all the other issues in the epic, we need to update the `UsageData` information to include the new counters.

This can be done in the method [`action_monthly_active_users`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data.rb#L595), adding the new 3 actions.

title: [Step 3] Update Snippet mutations to track edit events by snippet's editor
description:
We need to update the snippets' mutations to include the call to track the edit event performed by the snippets editor.

First, we need to get if the request was performed by the editor because it can also be made directly through GraphQL. For this, we can use the same approach we have in the commits API, and try to [find the user from warden](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/ee/api/helpers.rb#L155).

In case it's not possible we can change the FE code and include a new param that, if present, the mutation will call the metrics service.

title: [Step 3] Update BlobsController to track edit events by Single File Editor
description:
In order to track edit events performed by the Single File Editor, we need to update actions `create`, `update`, and `destroy` in the [`BlobController`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/controllers/projects/blob_controller.rb) and include the call to the metrics service.

We can also update the [`create_commit` method](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/controllers/concerns/creates_commit.rb#L8) and include a new keyword argument. Then, when the result is successful and that param is present, we will call the metrics service.

title: [Step 3] Update Commits API endpoint to track edit events by web IDE
description: We need to update the commits API endpoint to track this action when it was performed by the web IDE. We already have a Usage Data counter to [increment the number of commits](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/lib/api/commits.rb#L139) performed by the web IDE. We can leverage this and include the call to the new metric service.

title: Container Registry API bulk tag deletion is not respecting '+' metacharacter in complex regex
description:
**On gitlab.com**

### Summary

When sending a bulk tag deletion request to Container Registry API with a regular expression for filtering tags to keep that accepts several sub-regexes (`(?:x.*|v.+|latest|master|dev-.*|keep-.*)`), one of them (`v.+`) is not applied.

### Steps to reproduce

In a test project create several docker images with the following names:
```
dev-215
keep-special-image
latest
malandrin
malandro
v
v0.1.0
v1
v5
x
x1
x1.1-alpha2
y
```

Make an API call to bulk tag deletion method using the following parameters:
```
curl --request DELETE \
  --data "name_regex_delete=.*" \
  --data "name_regex_keep=(?:x.*|v.+|latest|master|dev-.*|keep-.*)" \
  --header "PRIVATE-TOKEN:<TOKEN>" \
  ${GITLAB_API_URL}/projects/<PROJECT_PROJECT_ID>/registry/repositories/<PROJECT_REPOSITORY_ID>/tags
```
This will return a `202` code.

After a while, this is the list of existing tags:
```
dev-215
keep-special-image
latest
x
x1
x1.1-alpha2
```

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The tags starting with 'v' have also been deleted despite the regex containing `v.+`.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Unless I'm missing something, the tags starting with 'v' shouldn't have been deleted.

The `v.+` is even one of the examples in the documentation of the cleanup policy for tags: `(?:v.+|master|release)` ([here](https://gitlab.com/help/user/packages/container_registry/index?rel=noopener+noreferrer&target=_blank#regex-pattern-examples)).

Indeed, if we replace `v.+` with `v.*` in the previous call, everything works as expected.

title: SafeParamsHelper::safe_params is not so safe
description:
**[HackerOne report #946728](https://hackerone.com/reports/946728)** by `vakzz` on 2020-07-29: ### Summary GitLab uses [SafeParamsHelper](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/682a3c0134f2cfec9e5743aa97fbaf2a7d89e65f/app/helpers/safe_params_helper.rb#L8) to filter out some keys before passing them to `url_for`: ```ruby def safe_params if params.respond_to?(:permit!) params.except(:host, :port, :protocol).permit! else params end end ``` The issue is that there are a [lot more dangerous keys](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/12f3f11f61eccc5d9423b288a08cb1fc7e60999b/actionpack/lib/action_dispatch/routing/route_set.rb#L781): ```ruby RESERVED_OPTIONS = [:host, :protocol, :port, :subdomain, :domain, :tld_length, :trailing_slash, :anchor, :params, :only_path, :script_name, :original_script_name, :relative_url_root] ``` This means that anywhere `safe_params` is used, the domain could be changed using the `domain` query. Most of the `build_canonical_path` methods call `url_for(safe_params)` which then gets used by [RoutableActions](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/682a3c0134f2cfec9e5743aa97fbaf2a7d89e65f/app/controllers/concerns/routable_actions.rb#L54): ```ruby def ensure_canonical_path(routable, requested_full_path) return unless request.get? canonical_path = routable.full_path if canonical_path != requested_full_path if !request.xhr? && request.format.html? && canonical_path.casecmp(requested_full_path) != 0 flash[:notice] = "#{routable.class.to_s.titleize} '#{requested_full_path}' was moved to '#{canonical_path}'. Please update any links and bookmarks that may still have the old path." end redirect_to build_canonical_path(routable) end end ``` This creates an open redirect in all of the `RoutableActions` routes by making `canonical_path != requested_full_path` (eg using a capital letter) and adding the `domain` param: 1. Visit https://gitlab.com/vakzz-h1/Redirect1?domain=aw.rs 1. You will be redirected to https://aw.rs/ The other key that can be abused is `script_name`, as this is appended to the start of the url and can be used to fake a protocol such as javascript: 1. Visit https://gitlab.com/vakzz-h1/redirect1/-/issues?script_name=javascript:alert(1)// 1. Look at the RSS Feed link ```html ``` 1. On gitlab.com this is blocked by the CSP There are a bunch of other places that use `safe_params` that could be exploited such as the [_viewer.html.haml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/682a3c0134f2cfec9e5743aa97fbaf2a7d89e65fapp/views/projects/blob/_viewer.html.haml#L7) ```haml - viewer_url = local_assigns.fetch(:viewer_url) { url_for(safe_params.merge(viewer: viewer.type, format: :json)) } if load_async .blob-viewer{ data: { type: viewer.type, rich_type: rich_type, url: viewer_url, path: viewer.blob.path }, class: ('hidden' if hidden) } ``` This allows an attacker to specify the `viewer_url` for the blob url. Since the json returned by the url has an `html` attributes it allows arbitrary html to be inserted. The below uses https://gitlab.com/-/snippets/1999965 as the viewer url and 1 click csp bypass (same as https://hackerone.com/reports/662287#activity-6026826) with https://gitlab.com/-/snippets/1999974/raw for the js payload: 1. Visit https://gitlab.com/vakzz-h1/redirect1/-/blob/master/test.txt?script_name=/-/snippets/1999965/raw%23 1. See the injected HTML: ```html
any html can go
``` 1. Clicking anywhere will trigger an alert I've only skimmed the other locations that use `safe_params` but it looks like there are a few more that load data via javascript or could be turned into open redirects. I also haven't looked into the impact of the open redirects to see if they could be escalated to leak sensitive information, I'll update the report if I find anything else. I've put all of these in a single report as the mitigation is the same for all of them, but if you would like me to split them into separate reports I can do that as well. I've also set the severity to high due to the number of places that this is used and relative ease of trigger it, but the individual issues are probably less so might need to be adjusted. ### What is the current *bug* behavior? `SafeParamsHelper.safe_params` only filters out the keys `:host, :port, :protocol` but there are other dangerous ones ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? `SafeParamsHelper.safe_params` should filter out all of the reserved options: ```ruby RESERVED_OPTIONS = [:host, :protocol, :port, :subdomain, :domain, :tld_length, :trailing_slash, :anchor, :params, :only_path, :script_name, :original_script_name, :relative_url_root] ``` ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com ## Impact * open redirect on quire a few routes * reflected xss using the `javascript` protocol * reflected xss with csp bypass using the blob viewer

title: [Step 1] Update Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::TrackUniqueActions to track new actions
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/35580, the service module [`Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::TrackUniqueActions`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/lib/gitlab/usage_data_counters/track_unique_actions.rb#L5) was introduced to track events that later will be consumed by Usage Data.

Nevertheless, this service class is very tight to the [`Event` model](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/models/event.rb) to a point in which it validates that the action to track is a valid action defined in that model.

The actions we want to track are quite particular since we don't create a real `Event` when the action is executed. Specifically, we want to track when a commit is performed:
- Through the web IDE
- Through the Single File Editor
- Through the Snippets editor

Therefore, we cannot fully rely on the `Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::TrackUniqueActions` service class because we need a custom set of actions and a payload that is different from the existing behavior.

That's why I'd proposed to create a service class named like `Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::TrackUniqueVirtualActions` that would extend the `Gitlab::UsageDataCounters::TrackUniqueActions` module.

This new service could be something like:

```ruby
module Gitlab
  module UsageDataCounters
    module TrackUniqueVirtualActions
      VIRTUAL_ACTIONS = %i[edit_by_web_ide edit_by_sfe edit_by_snippet_editor]

      class << self
        def track_action(event_action:, author_id:, time: Time.zone.now)
          return unless Gitlab::CurrentSettings.usage_ping_enabled
          return unless Feature.enabled?(FEATURE_FLAG)          
          return unless valid_action?(event_action)
          
          target_key = key(event_action, time)

          Gitlab::Redis::HLL.add(key: target_key, value: author_id, expiry: KEY_EXPIRY_LENGTH)
        end

        def count_unique_events(event_action:, date_from:, date_to:)
          keys = (date_from.to_date..date_to.to_date).map { |date| key(event_action, date) }

          Gitlab::Redis::HLL.count(keys: keys)
        end

        private                      

        def valid_action?(action)
          VIRTUAL_ACTIONS.key?(action)
        end

        def key(event_action, date)
          year_day = date.strftime('%G-%j')
          "#{year_day}-{#{event_action}}"
        end
      end
    end
  end
end
```

This is a quick approach to what would we need to achieve. We would need to think more about the action names and whether it's the best way for reusing it with other events.

Basically, this way we can store unique events related to virtual actions, we just need to figure out the programming nuances.

title: Warning on merge request diff when files collapsed
description:
### Problem to solve

Collapsing large files on a merge request diff is done to enhance the performance and responsiveness of the diff section in a merge request. However, the fact that some files are collapsed may be missed when scrolling through the list of files, causing some files to go unreviewed.

We have introduced a visible warning atop the merge request diff page, clearly informing the user when a file in the section is collapsed. This will ensure all related changes in the merge request are reviewed.

### Further details

Users have rightfully complained about how the current situation where we collapse some files for performance reasons might lead to **missing important changes** during code review.

This can lead to bugs, outages and other major problems in production for our users and customers.

Also, when reviewing code the reviewer might run a native browser "Find in page" to see the occurrences  of said variable/term. If they're not aware some areas are collapsed, they might be lead to believe it doesn't occur in the rest of the changes. But it might.

Make it clearly visible when at least ONE diff file is collapsed. In the warning add a button to "expand all".

**Note**: we might want to add a slight note in a popover/tooltip that expanding all at once might cause some performance problems.

### User experience goal

Make users easily and clearly aware when the content shown is only a partial view of the whole set of changes

### Proposal

It would be beneficial to set a priority order for the alerts shown above the diff. Today, we have two alerts: when there are too many files to show and when there are merge conflicts ([mockup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/81d8a9e1593365eda696c11c546d14d9/image.png)). With this issue, we will have a third case: when some files are collapsed by default. To avoid the situation where we show 2 or 3 of those alerts at the same time, we could set a priority to show only one at a time, like so:

1. Merge conflicts
1. Too many files to show
1. Some files are collapsed by default

As for the alert to be introduced in this issue, **some files are collapsed by default**:

![mock](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/cc9688cf6a40f1309341723e7e4f0cf1/image.png)

However, as it's rightly noted in the description, it should still be visible if users follow a link to a discussion/file (i.e., make it somehow sticky). Today, those two alerts shown above the diffs are not sticky, so we should change that too.

### Further details

* Shouldn't apply in File-by-file mode
* It should still be visible if users follow a link to a discussion/file. ie, make it somehow sticky.

### Stretch goals

1. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/243572: Adapt the existing “Too many files to show” big, orange alert so it conforms with our Pajamas guidelines on alerts and is consistent with the other alerts shown above the diff. Also make the UI copy a bit easier to understand.
1. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/243573: Move the `Show latest version` and `Expand all` buttons to the left, after the comparison dropdowns, so they are more visible.
1. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/243574: Change the button label to “Expand all {+files+}” so that the action is crystal clear.

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

Add a section to diffs mentioning an increased awareness if any content has been "hidden" for performance reasons.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

Reviewers stop missing important changes. We can assess this via qualitative surveys.

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

<!-- Communicate if this change will affect multiple Stage Groups or product areas. We recommend always start with the assumption that a feature request will have an impact into another Group. Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

~"devops::create" ~"group::source code" only.

### Release notes

Collapsing large files on a merge request diff is done to enhance the performance and responsiveness of the diff section in a merge request. However, the fact that some files are collapsed may be missed when scrolling through the list of files, causing some files to go unreviewed.

We have introduced a visible warning atop the merge request diff page, clearly informing the user when a file in the section is collapsed. This will ensure all related changes in the merge request are reviewed.

![collapsed_diff](/uploads/758f22fff9773330c116b27782068653/collapsed_diff.png)

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/reviewing_and_managing_merge_requests.html#merge-request-diff-file-navigation

title: Support HTTPS proxy settings of RetireJS
description:
NOTE if you are a user who also would like to see this feature, please UPVOTE 👍 it and comment to help it get prioritized (So it’s raised as part of our [sensing mechanisms]( https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/product-management/process/#sensing-mechanism). Comments ideally should include what you want, how it would help you, what your pain point/frustration is today, and anything else that can help us focus on solving the problem.

If you are a team member commenting on behalf of a user (not ideal, as you can only upvote once!) Please remember to upvote and include as much information (what they are trying to solve for, their setup) as possible in addition to a salesforce or zendesk link.


<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release Notes

Thanks to community contributor ankur sethi and their patience Dependency Scanning now supports proxy settings in RetireJS by respecting the `HTTPS_PROXY` environment variable. If `HTTPS_PROXY` is set, it will be passed to the `retire` command line as a CLI option. Thank you!

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a software developer I want to run retirejs behind a corporate proxy so I do not have to create and maintain the `RETIREJS_JS_ADVISORY_DB` and `RETIREJS_NODE_ADVISORY_DB` manually.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Developers, DevOps Engineers

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Currently retire.js's proxy support is unused because it does not respect the `HTTPS_PROXY` environment variables. If `HTTPS_PROXY` is set, it should be pass to the `retire` command line as a CLI option.

### Proposal

The retire.js analyzer should check for the `HTTPS_PROXY` environment variable being set. If set it should set the `--proxy` option of the `retire` command accordingly.

~~Alternatively you can give a Retire.JS command line ENV variable which can be configured for the dependency scanner. This will allow setting additional options.~~

### Implementation plan

- [x] add support for `HTTPS_PROXY` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js/-/merge_requests/93
- [x] add specific test to the CI config (downstream pipeline using a supported Secure test project)
- [ ] ~~update [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning)~~ This is a generic variable that we do not document explicitely. We might have a generic statement added for these variables: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/76410

### Further details

If you check out the README for the retire.js command line you will notice it has an entry for Proxy URL:

```
  --proxy <url>            Proxy url (http://some.sever:8080)
```

Further if you check the code
https://github.com/RetireJS/retire.js/blob/1aba081b5d5363add13710edeb470d5eb4f3c914/node/lib/repo.js

```javascript
if (options.proxy) {
reqOptions.agent = new HttpsProxyAgent(options.proxy);
}
```

You can see that it does not use the `HTTPS_PROXY` env variables. It relies on the the command line option being set to use the proxy. Therefore retire.js does not support a proxy from the ENV variables and there is no way to configure the options to retire.js from the Dependency Scanner.

### Permissions and Security

N/A

### Documentation

~~To be documented in [Configuring specific analyzers used by dependency scanning](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/dependency_scanning/#configuring-specific-analyzers-used-by-dependency-scanning)~~ See implementation plan.

We might also add a doc section about setting up HTTPS proxies. This section would list the Dependency Scanning analyzers supporting proxy settings.

### Availability & Testing

To be tested using one of the supported Secure test projects:
1. create a new branch in [tests/js-npm](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-npm) or [tests/js-yarn](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-yarn) where a proxy is set up; see [offline-FREEZE](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-npm/-/blob/offline-FREEZE/.gitlab-ci.yml#L34) branch of `tests/js-npm`
1. update the CI configuration of the [retire.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js) analyzer, and add a QA job that uses this branch and where `HTTPS_PROXY` is set in the `variables` of the job definition; see [`js-npm-offline-qa`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/retire.js/-/blob/v2.11.1/.gitlab-ci.yml#L23)

The test should set up a proxy to access [jsrepository.json](https://github.com/RetireJS/retire.js/blob/master/repository/jsrepository.json), [npmrepository.json](https://github.com/RetireJS/retire.js/blob/master/repository/npmrepository.json), and to npmjs.com. Direct access to these must be blocked. All this can be done in the `before_script` of the scanning job, similar to what is done for the `offline-FREEZE` branch. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/js-npm/-/blob/offline-FREEZE/.gitlab-ci.yml#L34

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

The Retire.js analyzer runs behind an HTTPS proxy.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No

### Links / references

title: Fix icon for submodules in merge requests
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

In commits and merge requests, Git submodules use a generic file type icon, which is not consistent with the repository view.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add/change/remove a Git submodule from a repository
1. View the file list in a commit or merge request

### Example Project

- Commit: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-test/-/commit/e695d8808466eaeb640217becfc7c107c03f5219?merge_request_iid=52
- Merge request: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-test/-/merge_requests/52/diffs

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Submodules use a generic file type icon, which is not consistent with the repository view (see below).

| Commit | Merge request |
|---|---|
| ![image](/uploads/8cc997506f5977e87ca9ccc567bda3be/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/2e28afdbd035b49814a04fbe03ffa4b4/image.png) |

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Submodules should use the corresponding file type icon, as seen in the repository (example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-test)

![image](/uploads/f3a00576e507f303b1090e133bc20434/image.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

title: Instrument CI Authoring Funnel: First Green Pipeline
description:
### Problem to solve

Today we are unsure of the success rate of customers attempting to author CI yaml files and get to their new project's first green build. This means our prioritization of improvements to the authoring process related to this metric aren't guided by product data.

### Intended users

* GitLab Product Managers
* GitLab Developers
* GitLab Community Contributors

### Proposal

Record, for every project that has not already run a pipeline and is not using Auto DevOps:

- The date and time the first pipeline is run
- A count of each time a pipeline runs (inclusive of the one above), until the first time a pipeline succeeds
- The date and time the first time a pipeline succeeds

We would need some kind of sisense dashboard that shows how this is trending over time.

#### Examples

If a person has a success their first try, and their build runs for 10 minutes, the data would look something like the following (YAML is used here just for illustration purposes):

```yaml
my_project:
  first_run: 2020-06-01 10:00AM PST
  count: 1
  first_success: 2020-06-01 10:10AM PST
```

Someone who has been trying different things for a month with no success would look something like the following:

```yaml
my_other_project:
  first_run: 2020-01-03 9:30AM PST
  count: 54
  first_success: false
```

### Technical proposal

we can have a table like `ci_project_pipeline_statistics`, and store the data in it.

### Further details

title: Show ZAP rule execution time in scan summary
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Different DAST scan rules take varying amount of time to complete depending on the target web application. If scan rule execution time is provided in the scan summary it will help to identify the long running scan rules. Users can then take action on long running scan rules like disable them if it's not important/relevant or tweak the scans parameters to make the rule complete fasters. This will ultimately help users to configure faster and effective DAST scans.

### Intended users


* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)

### User experience goal

User should be able to see execution time of each scan rule in the scan summary e.g

```
PASS: Cross Site Scripting (Persistent) - Prime [40016]: Took 10 minutes
PASS: Remote Code Execution - Shell Shock [10048]: Took 150 minutes
PASS: Cross Site Scripting (Persistent) - Spider [40017]: Took 20 minutes
PASS: Script Active Scan Rules [50000]: Took 7 minutes
PASS: Source Code Disclosure - Git  [41]: Took 2 minutes
PASS: Source Code Disclosure - File Inclusion [43]: Took 30 minutes
```
Now user can identify `Remote Code Execution - Shell Shock [10048]` takes 150 mins and is the major reason the scan takes longer time to complete. User can now make a call if this rule is applicable to the target application or is it worth running this rule for 150 minutes and disable or keep it running.

### Proposal

Currently zap.out logs does generate logs per scan rule with the time taken for execution. Time from these logs can be collected and added up per scan rule to display it along with the scan summary. 

> [zap.out] 3937350 [Thread-8] INFO org.parosproxy.paros.core.scanner.HostProcess  - completed host/plugin https://scan-target.com | TestExternalRedirect in 2813.043s with 33151 message(s) sent and 0 alert(2020-07-28 05:08:43,565 Starting new HTTP connection (1): localhost:46374

#### Implementation Plan

`ScanSummaryService` already possesses a list of each alert with its history record. We can use sum of the `timeelapsedmillis` field from the history records for all alerts found by a given rule to get the total time the rule took to execute.

1. Add `timeelapsedmillis` to the fields fetched by `HttpMessagesQuery` and the properties of `HttpMessage`
1. In `ScanSummaryService`, sum up the time elapsed values for every alert related to a plugin, and add that number to the rule summary printed. Ex: `PASS: Source Code Disclosure - File Inclusion [43]: Took 30 minutes`
1. Print the result as seconds if < 60 seconds, or minutes otherwise

title: Include the installation instructions for Composer dependencies in the Package Registry UI
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

Users can now view their Composer dependencies in the GitLab Package Registry through the UI. However, it doesn't include information enabling the user to quickly utilize the package.

### Intended users


* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)

### User experience goal

A user is provided with dynamic information on how to quickly install the Composer Package.

### Proposal

Include a "Registry Setup" section in the composer registry with a copy enabled code snippet plus links to the relevant documentation.

| Suggested UI |
|---|
|![Composer_Install_Instructions](/uploads/dac2866f1410ca09b5b7baeebf2a71e0/Composer_Install_Instructions.png)|

### Further details

The design does not include "install instructions" and only registry setup. Should we consider the section header to be more generic across the package registry UI? 

This design is based on the assumption we'll implement the single-column layout. I can create an additional comp if we want to get these instructions into the current two-column-table-tab-in-a-tab layout.

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members

title: Ignore scan.scanner.version in compare_reports.sh
description:
### Problem to solve

Now that a `scan.scanner.version` field is being added to the reports generated by our analyzers, as part of [Add scanner, report_type to SAST, CS, DS reports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/202053), we need to ignore this value in the [compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/7e7dd770e3f0ecf7ab856cf088759ac4f5c19d94/scripts/compare_reports.sh) script, otherwise, every time the analyzer version is bumped, the integration tests will fail.

See [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/merge_requests/54#note_386612083) for more details.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

The version of an analyzer can be changed without needing to update integration tests

### Proposal

Update the `jq_filter` in the [`"ds" | "sast" | "it"`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/7e7dd770e3f0ecf7ab856cf088759ac4f5c19d94/scripts/compare_reports.sh#L50-56) conditional to ignore the `version` value by adding: `del(.scan.scanner.version)`

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

A new analyzer with an updated version value can be created without needing to update the integration tests to accommodate the new version value.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"Enterprise Edition" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, this will affect all Secure analyzer projects

### Links / references

title: Move version check script to ci-templates/analyzer.yml
description:
### Problem to solve

Now that a `scan.scanner.version` field is being added to the reports generated by our analyzers, as part of [Add scanner, report_type to SAST, CS, DS reports](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/202053), we need to add sanity-checking to ensure that the version reported by the analyzer binary matches the most recent version provided by the `CHANGELOG.md` file.

Logic for checking the `app.Version` value currently exists only in [container scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/klar/-/blob/6b8699da5ad515b84b21bf44b318e3c4d8057994/.gitlab-ci.yml#L9-18). The purpose of this issue is to move this logic to the [analyzer.yml template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/7e7dd770e3f0ecf7ab856cf088759ac4f5c19d94/includes-dev/analyzer.yml) in the `ci-templates` project so that all Go-based analyzers can benefit from this sanity check.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

This will prevent analyzers from being released with a mismatch between the binary version and the version reported in the `CHANGELOG.md`

### Proposal

- If the version _is not configured_, output a warning message in the `version-check` stage, but **do not fail the job**. This will prevent breaking existing analyzers that don't yet report the version.
- If the version _is configured_ 
  - and the version _matches_ the most recent version in `CHANGELOG.md`, print out a successful message
  - and the version _does not match_ the most recent version in `CHANGELOG.md`, print out an error message and **fail the job**

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Manually test to verify the behaviour described in the [proposal](#proposal) section.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"Enterprise Edition" 

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, this will affect all Go-based secure analyzer projects.

title: Follow-up - Add singular/plural form text to merge request button for License-Check approvals
description:
As a follow up to: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231250

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231250 was a version one of a hard coded string that accomedated the messaging for having the merge request button disabled. (Single and multiple licenses being `Denied` in the MR)

This was done as a version 1 and to reduce complexity of delivering https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/196845

-----

This issue is a **follow-up** and improvement to make the messaging dynamic for the single and multiple denied licenses.



## Implementation Plan

## Option 1: Pass data in mr object

We need to add the data we need to the following endpoints:

`https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37191/widget.json`

and/or 

`https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37191/cached_widget.json`

endpoint which requires ~backend.

### Where to Add the Data:

#### We would add it to the `license_scanning` object.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/serializers/ee/merge_request_widget_entity.rb#L38

#### It's assigned to the MrWidgetStore in:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/mr_widget_store.js#L31

#### Example passed in as a prop in:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/mr_widget_options.vue#L344

#### MrWidgetPolicyViolation Component is selected in:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/mr_widget_options.vue#L107

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/state_maps.js#L7

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/get_state_key.js#L10

#### Access the MR object from within MrWidgetPolicyViolation

We'd need to add a MR prop. Example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/states/mr_widget_secondary_geo_node.vue#L13

We'd access the data we need as `mr.licenseScanning.<DATA_WE_NEED>`


---------------------------

## Option 2: Pass endpoint data we need, and do additional async request from within the MrWidgetPolicyViolation component.

We need to add the licenses endpoint path to:

`https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37191/widget.json`

and/or 

`https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37191/cached_widget.json`

endpoint which requires ~backend. 

### Where to add the path:

#### We would add it to the `license_scanning` object.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/serializers/ee/merge_request_widget_entity.rb#L38

Something like `project_licenses_path`

#### `license_scanning` object is assigned to the MrWidgetStore in:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/mr_widget_store.js#L31

#### Example passed in as a prop in:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/mr_widget_options.vue#L344

#### MrWidgetPolicyViolation Component is selected in:

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/mr_widget_options.vue#L107

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/state_maps.js#L7

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/stores/get_state_key.js#L10

#### Access the MR object from within MrWidgetPolicyViolation

We'd need to add a MR prop. Example: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/states/mr_widget_secondary_geo_node.vue#L13

We'd access the data we need as `mr.licenseScanning.project_licenses_path`

#### The ajax request:

In the `MrWidetPolicyViolation` component we'd initialize a store similar to how we do for 

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/license_compliance/mr_widget_license_report.vue#L14

The `MrWidgetLicenseReport` is a working example of how we do an AJAX request within a single vue component on the MR page. It is done for the License scan MR widget.

The `MrWidgetLicenses` component is aliased and rendered in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/mr_widget_options.vue#L342

We do the same for `MrWidetPolicyViolation` in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/vue_merge_request_widget/components/states/mr_widget_policy_violation.vue

#### Leverage the existing LICENSE_LIST vuex module to handle store, actions, getters, and mutations.

We can use the `LICENSE_LIST` vuex module defined in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/license_compliance/store/modules/list/index.js

This is instead of the `LICENSE_MANAGEMENT` vuex module that is used in `MrWidgetLicenseReport`.

The difference is this.

`LICENSE_MANAGEMENT` - covers anything to do with defining license policies

`LICENSE_LIST` - covers anything to do with detected licenses in the project.


## In Summary for Option 2:

Actual work involves,

Adding resource path to json path, defining prop in `mr-widget-policy-violation-component`, making use of the actions and getters in the `LICENSE_LIST` vuex module, rendering singular/plural version of text.

title: Increase the Epic Nesting from 5 to 7
description: ### Problem to solve Many internal users are finding the 5 level nesting restriction frustrating, as we are planning larger collections of work mapped to OKRs and Category maturity initiatives. ### Intended users * [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager) * [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead) ### Proposal **Increase the number of epics users can nest under a parent epic from 5 to 7** as an iterative step to asses any performance or usability issues prior to additional expansion. A concern to discuss, as Epics are nested within the Epic Tree, they are indented right on expansion. If we extend the limit of nesting, we will need account for this deeper indentation and the affect it will have on the cards themselves and the information listed (organization of info, truncation, etc) ###### :art: Figma specs https://www.figma.com/file/kZV3su3DQhYZiqkQiCimjp/Nesting-depth-exploration?node-id=95%3A273 | Tree nesting | Roadmap nesting | | ------ | ------ | | | | ### Documentation Would need to update our Epics documentation and marketing materials (will track these down) ### What does success look like, and how can we measure that? - Increased adoption of Epics and Epic nesting internally at GitLab ### Links / references

description:
## Problem

When viewing the MR Analytics page, I want to be able to view the individual MRs that are in the chart to better understand the underlying MRs that drove the trend.

## Proposal

When viewing MR Analytics, show the individual merged MRs depicted in the throughput chart in a data table:

![Throughput_table_+_chart_MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/7ff1af3de5f0acb3f9b66724fe05da8d/Throughput_table_+_chart_MVC.png)

* Limit to the first 100 records, sorted by id/created_at (per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229365#note_382190171)
* Columns to show:
  * Date merged
  * Time to merge
  * Milestone
  * Comments
  * Commits
  * Approvals (number of approvals)
  * Pipelines (with a check if the MR passed CI when merged)
  * Line changes

### Out of scope

* Sorting by column will be implemented in a follow-up: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/230562
* Pagination will be implemented in a follow-up: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/229842

title: Failed DAST jobs are shown as succeeded in pipeline
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

DAST jobs terminated with runtime errors like `java.lang.OutOfMemoryError` are shown as succeeded in pipeline. Looks like DAST job does not return an error exit code, which could be used by the runner to determine if the job ran successfully or not.

### Steps to reproduce

This occurs when the DAST job terminates unexpectedly on a runtime error like out of memory error.

### Example Project

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/658921824
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/658921823
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/jobs/657131425

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
DAST jobs are shown as succeeded even when the job failed due to runtime errors.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

DAST job should be shown as failed in the pipeline when the job fails dues to any runtime errors.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

title: Spike: Determine why unpausing indexing stopped half way through and make it more robust
description:
## Problem

We observed an instance where unpausing the indexing didn't actually requeue all the indexing jobs that were queued up while paused. If we didn't have good monitoring on this we might have missed that and some indexing would have been missed.

## Details

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2408#note_386531952 I unpaused the indexing and I noticed that it didn't fully finish the unpausing. I couldn't tell why since I only see a [start log for `ElasticIndexingControlWorker`](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:'2020-07-27T21:09:58.044Z',to:'2020-07-28T06:09:55.728Z'))&_a=(columns:!(_source),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:AWNABDRwNDuQHTm2tH6l,key:json.class.keyword,negate:!f,params:(query:ElasticIndexingControlWorker),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.class.keyword:ElasticIndexingControlWorker)))),index:AWNABDRwNDuQHTm2tH6l,interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:ElasticIndexingControlWorker),sort:!())) . 

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-28_at_4.04.46_pm](/uploads/7f9d4055e0900067fd9d1d008d976549/Screen_Shot_2020-07-28_at_4.04.46_pm.png)

Perhaps this processed was somehow killed in the middle of resuming all the jobs. Graphs indicate it just stopped at some point:

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-28_at_4.04.36_pm](/uploads/ccb9bc665507feb5ff61bd6babd18e77/Screen_Shot_2020-07-28_at_4.04.36_pm.png)

Since there were still ~260k jobs to be requeued I went ahead and kicked it off again:

```rb
[ gprd ] production> Elastic::IndexingControlService.new(ElasticCommitIndexerWorker).queue_size
=> 259652
[ gprd ] production> ElasticIndexingControlWorker.new.perform
=> true
[ gprd ] production> Elastic::IndexingControlService.new(ElasticCommitIndexerWorker).queue_size
=> 0
```

## Solution

Figure out why it could have failed like this and make it more robust. If we cannot figure out why we may choose to make it more robust in a different way. For example we could check periodically if there are paused jobs and kick off the worker again if necessary.

title: Document how we normalize Scanner's severity values
description:
### Problem to solve

It is unclear how we normalize our Severity values from the raw data provided by the different Scanner we integrate.

### Intended users

~"devops::secure" team members

### User experience goal

As a Secure team member, I want to better understand how we generate the severity values of the reported findings.

### Proposal


Adds a new technical doc under https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/secure/tech-docs/ to explain how we do the severity mapping.

This should contain a generic description of the process and then a breakdown per analyzer, with a link to the corresponding source code.


### Is this a cross-stage feature?

- ~"group::composition analysis" 
- ~"group::dynamic analysis"
- ~"group::static analysis" 


### Links / references

title: Update the milestone dropdown combobox to display separated sections and badge counters
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

In order to complete the feature proposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476, we'll need to change the existing [`milestone dropdown combobox`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/milestones/project_milestone_combobox.vue) component to look like the propose prototype: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476/designs/group-milestone-3.png

To do this, we'll want to allow for the component to have multiple separated sections. In the section headers there should be a badge counter of how many items are in each section. The search functionality should return results that narrow each section down.

This issue does not cover the scope of populating the dropdown with group milestones on the release edit page. That will be covered in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232577 

### Intended users


* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

The developer should be able to pass in props to make it so that this component renders multiple sections, each with a counter of how many items are in each section.

The user should be able to use this UI in order to select items from multiple sections. For example, project milestones and group milestones. They should be able to see how many items are in each section, and should be able to enter a single search term that returns results in each section.


### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->


Update the current `milestone dropdown combobox` component to be able to have separated sections and badge counters like the proposed design. The search functionality should return results in each section. Change the name of that component from [project_milestone_combobox.vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/milestones/project_milestone_combobox.vue) to milestone_combobox.vue

description:

### Out of scope

These elements were originally part of this proposal, but were moved elsewhere:

- Update "Advanced" section description in Project's "General Settings". Incidentally executed by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/78290.
```patch

+ Housekeeping, export, archive, change path, transfer, and delete project.
```

title: Ensure that we flush chunks into permament storage once a full chunk is received
description:
Currently, when using Live Traces and a full chunk is received
we schedule async operation to flush the chunk from `Redis` to `DB/OS`.

## Proposal

Introduce the following barriers into a process:

1. When a chunk is received, the persist operation is synchronous
2. When a final update is received, all chunks should be marked as persisted, and no longer be allowed to be appended

## Outcome

This would improve a live traces resiliency, by:

1. Ensuring that all data is persisted
2. Ensuring that we can safely and timely archive all data without having Redis to expire them
3. Introducing barriers (flush/syncs) into the process

Related code:

```ruby
    def schedule_to_persist
      return if data_persisted?

      Ci::BuildTraceChunkFlushWorker.perform_async(id)
    end
```

## Patching

Additionally, we could consider accepting no more than 3-4 chunks per single `PATCH`, and return an accepted offset
for Runner to resent. Runner, already today sends a chunked `PATCHes`, but this can be a way to ensure that other
users adhere to this operation as well: limited patching operation.

title: Parse composite license expressions
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

A software package can be covered by more than one software license. The [SPDX standard](https://spdx.dev/) describes a way to express these relationships using a [SPDX License Expression](https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/appendix-IV-SPDX-license-expressions/#composite-license-expressions). The SPDX license expression allows a software author to express their software packages license via `AND`, `OR`, `WITH` exception.

E.g.

* `BSD-2-Clause OR MIT`
* `(GPL-2.0 AND MIT AND BSD-3-Clause)`
* `(GPL-3.0+ WITH Bison-Exception)`

I propose that the `license_scanning` job should be able to detect these license expressions and display these in the UI in a way that represents the expressions.

### Intended users

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

When a software dependency is covered by more than one software license, this is displayed in the UI as `AND`, `OR` etc.

### Proposal

* Update the `license_scanning` job to parse the `SPDX` expression.
* Update the `gl-license-scanning-report.json` to represent the `AND`, `OR`, `WITHOUT` relationships.
* Update the UI to display the `AND`, `OR`, `WITHOUT` relationships.

### Further details

This issue addresses the need to parse the SPDX expressions so that they can be included in the report. A followup issue will be required to introduce a new report version that will allow representing different composite expressions such as AND, OR, WITH. An array of licenses is not enough information to determine if this licenses in the array represent an AND or OR relation.

E.g.

The following tells us that the software dependency is licensed under BSD-2-Clause, MIT but it does not tell us if it is licensed under BSD-2-Clause and MIT or if it is licensed under BSD-2-Clause or MIT.

```json
"licenses": [
  "BSD-2-Clause",
  "MIT"
]
```

A new major version of the report schema may need to be introduced to handle these types of scenarios.

### Permissions and Security

TBD

### Documentation

TBD

### Availability & Testing

The test fixtures will need to be updated. 

E.g. [source](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/blob/7a01aa5dba4b8df24419c2e45ead6efe5698a0a9/spec/fixtures/expected/js/yarn/v2.1.json#L8226)

Before:

```json
"licenses": [
  "(bsd-2-clause or mit or apache-2.0)"
]
```

After:

```json
"licenses": [
  "BSD-2-Clause",
  "MIT",
  "Apache-2.0"
]
```

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

A software package that is covered by `AND`, `OR`, `WITH` expressions are understood by end users when viewing a license scanning widget from the `License Compliance` page or MR widget.

### What is the type of buyer?

GitLab Ultimate

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

No.

### Links / references

* https://spdx.dev
* https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/appendix-IV-SPDX-license-expressions/#composite-license-expressions
* Example parser: https://github.com/spandx/spandx/blob/master/lib/spandx/spdx/expression.rb

### Implementation Plan

* [x] Parse SPDX expressions from detected license names [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/blob/8ee0824204c0e97d97ad6d38778cd9e7e9da6813/lib/license/finder/ext/dependency.rb#L22) using [spandx](https://github.com/spandx/spandx/blob/cce394463963abc30e5b53b6478106c60ac20166/lib/spandx/spdx/expression.rb). 
* [x] Add each license from a composite expression in to the [report](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/license-management/-/blob/7a01aa5dba4b8df24419c2e45ead6efe5698a0a9/spec/fixtures/expected/js/yarn/v2.1.json#L8226). Future work may require a separate issue to differentiate between OR, AND, WITH in the report format.

title: Update Release pages Vuex stores to handle Group milestones assocaited with a release
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a breakdown of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476#note_384809928, one thing we'll want to do is update the Releases [Vuex stores](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/releases/stores/index.js) to handle getting, creating, updating, and deleting group milestone *associations* (not the group milestones themselves) with a release. These updates should allow for the group milestones to be displayed (and linked) on the Releases page, along with allowing for group milestone associations to be fetched, created, updated, and deleted on the Release edit page.

To assist with this, a ~backend MR will be needed to modify the [releases API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/) to allow for submissions that `GET`, `POST`, `UPDATE`, and `DELETE` group milestone associations with a release. This will create a new `group_milestones` attribute in the [releases API](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/releases/).

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)


### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Update and test the Releases [Vuex stores](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/releases/stores/index.js) to handle Group milestone associations with a release using a to-be-added `group_milestone` attribute (separate ~backend MR.)

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

Benefits the completion of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476 by making an iterative step towards being able to create the proposed UI.

### Permissions and Security

* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [x] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Availability & Testing

Unit tests and updates will likely need to be added in:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/spec/frontend/releases/stores/modules/detail/actions_spec.js
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/spec/frontend/releases/stores/modules/detail/getters_spec.js
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/spec/frontend/releases/stores/modules/detail/mutations_spec.js
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/spec/frontend/releases/mock_data.js

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

After making this Vuex modifications, it should be possible to make group milestone selection work in the milestone dropdown combobox UI proposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476

title: Add Group milestones API (GET) methods to api.js
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a breakdown of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476#note_384809928, one thing we'll want to do is add methods to [api.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/api.js) to get [Group milestones](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_milestones.html).  We'll want this so that we can populate the milestones dropdown combobox with Group milestones to select from to be associated (or unassociated) with a release.

For the purpose of this problem, we likely only need methods for these two API calls:

```
GET /groups/:id/milestones
GET /groups/:id/milestones?search=version
```

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?

https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

As an internal developer, it should be possible to get and search for group milestones using tested methods in [api.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/api.js).


### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Add methods to [api.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/api.js) to get [Group milestones](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/group_milestones.html) using these endpoints:

```
GET /groups/:id/milestones
GET /groups/:id/milestones?search=version
```

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

This benefits the development of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/121476#note_384809928 by making it possible to populate the proposed milestone dropdown combobox.
