title: Improve performance of show action for Projects::CommitController under load into S2 tier
description:
After adding in a new test for the Commit details page it was found that the `show` action for the `Projects::CommitController` is unperformant:

```
* Environment:                10k
* Environment Version:        13.3.0-pre `9cda1414a43`
* Option:                     60s_200rps
* Date:                       2020-07-28
* Run Time:                   1m 15.64s (Start: 09:10:21 UTC, End: 09:11:37 UTC)
* GPT Version:                v2.0.5

NAME               | RPS  | RPS RESULT       | TTFB AVG  | TTFB P90              | REQ STATUS     | RESULT
-------------------|------|------------------|-----------|-----------------------|----------------|----------------
web_project_commit | 20/s | 5.78/s (>3.20/s) | 2997.63ms | 10127.84ms (<12500ms) | 100.00% (>95%) | Passed

    http_req_waiting.....................: avg=2997.63ms min=54.91ms   med=85.65ms   max=13182.73ms p(90)=10127.84ms p(95)=10337.54ms
    ✓ { endpoint:branches }..............: avg=96.55ms   min=54.91ms   med=64.62ms   max=556.35ms   p(90)=202.32ms   p(95)=217.91ms
    ✓ { endpoint:commit }................: avg=9819.58ms min=8657.37ms med=9493.09ms max=13182.73ms p(90)=11369.70ms p(95)=11647.16ms
    ✓ { endpoint:merge_requests.json }...: avg=118.61ms  min=62.87ms   med=73.31ms   max=1267.09ms  p(90)=208.43ms   p(95)=233.60ms
```

These were tested on our 10k Reference Architecture with a RPS target of 20/s against a real large commit (86 changed files with 1992 additions and 135 deletions, can be seen on staging [here](https://staging.gitlab.com/gpt/large_projects/gitlabhq1/-/commit/8f9beefac3774b30e911fb00a68f4c7a5244cf27)) spread across each controller action.

As per our [performance targets](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/issue-triage/#severity) these controller actions are above our main target of 500ms and fall under the ~S1  tier. Task is to improve each action's performance into the next tier ~S2 (<9000ms).

title: Change name of readonly ability `license_management`
description:
The following discussion from !36734 should be addressed:

- [ ] @tyleramos started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36734#note_385279420):  (+4 comments)

    > I noticed a "bug" in the original code where `:license_management` was listed as a READONLY feature [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36734/diffs#edcbe28bdecbd848d4d9efdc5b5e9bddd2a7299e_14_8).  However, `:license_management` isn't actually a feature (iow. `:*_license_management` abilities don't exist).  What does exist and probably the original intent was `:admin_software_license_policy` which I've added here instead, and removed `:license_management` from the `locked_features` below.

`:license_management` is [listed here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/36734/diffs#edcbe28bdecbd848d4d9efdc5b5e9bddd2a7299e_14_8) as a read_only feature, but this should be listed as `:software_license_policy` instead.  `:license_manangement` isn't a real ability that is being checked.

title: Show deployment status in the environment page
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a user, I want to know that there is a deployment going on in my environment.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager) 
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops) 
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
-->

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

The user will be able to know the status of a deployment directly from the environment page

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->


- Add the deployment status to the `deployment` column of `/environments` page for each row. 
  - The deployment status and deployment ID, plus author will either reflect the latest successful deployment or one which is in progress. 
  - The deployment status will be displayed with a single status icon positioning after the deployment ID
  - The deployment author will be positioned on a second line below the deployment ID and status.
  - The deployment status will link towards the deployment job responsible (similar to the environment detail page)
  - Canceled or failed deployments will not show as these do not represent what is present in the environment.
  - The deployment status will feature a tooltip stating `Deployment <status>`:
    - Running `Deployment in progress`
    - Success: `Deployment successful`
- When an "upcoming" deployment exists, update the **Job** and **Commit** columns to point to the new deployment's job ID and commit info.

| Mockup (Browser made)   |
| --- |
| ![image](/uploads/39414af4c0ca7ae999ee8976705e58f1/image.png) |

#### Background: Current vs Upcoming deployments

In environment index page, the most essential information for operators/RMs/SREs is the **current** deployment on the environment (or sometimes we refer it as *last* or *last successful deployment*). Today, we show it, and on top of that there are some advanced metrics or controls on the **current** deployment. For example:

* Is there any critical alerts caused by the current deployment? => [We show alerts in footer](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#view-the-latest-alerts-for-environments).
* Can I monitor how the current deployment is performing on the environment? => Click ["Monitoring" button](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#monitoring-environments)
* Can I see the website of the current deployment? => Click ["Open live environment" button](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#using-the-environment-url).
* Can I stop the environment? => Click "Stop environment" button. Important note: this [automatically triggers a corresponding stop job](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#stopping-an-environment) in the **same pipeline** with the current deployment job. Given current and upcoming deployments run in different pipelines, this makes a similar confusion @nfriend pointed above.
* Can I re-deploy the current deployment? => Click "Re-deploy to environment" button.
* and more

So almost all of the features on this environment index page were designed for the **current** deployment, which is what actually exists on the environment. We should keep the current UX, otherwise we need to revisit the concepts of the above features for running deployment, just like [a proposal to hide button suggested by @nfriend](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232494#note_458401988). We need to do similar follow-up for the rest of the features as well, which probably we cannot afford.

The main purpose of this issue is showing a complementary information about "what's the next deployment?". The next deployment job could be [a manual job](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/incremental_rollouts.html#manual-rollouts) that is waiting for operators executing the job, or it could be [a scheduled job](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/incremental_rollouts.html#timed-rollouts) that will be automatically executed after a specific period, or it could be a normal job that will be executed after an upstream stage jobs have finished, or it could be being deployed (i.e. running) by one of the above paths. I'm referring these type of deployment jobs as "upcoming deployments", but please let me know if there is a better terminology.

Now, this issue should be fairly easy to be accomplished if we simply add a new column, because it doesn't affect the current behavior thus require no follow-ups. For the MVC sake, this issue targets only running status as a upcoming deployment, however, I believe this feature should be extended as above.

#### Payload change

We'll change the `environments.json` payload to have `last_deployment` and `upcoming_deployment` per environment. The `upcoming_deployment` payload is formatted in the same schema with `last_deployment`.

This `upcoming_deployment` is selected by the following criteria:

* Deployments with `running` status.
* Newer `deployment` object than the latest/current deployment.
* When there are multiple candidates, the latest one is returned i.e. the largest `deployments.id`.
* If there is no relevant record, it returns `nil` or the key doesn't exist in the hash.

A few notes:

- It only contains necessary data to present the UI and excludes some unnecessary metadata such as `manual_actions`, `scheduled_actions` to save up some payload size.

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

The user currently has no way of knowing that a deployment is in progress when viewing the environment page.
This is super useful with the connectivity of [showing alerts in the environment page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/214634) as this will give the user an indication of what action they can take during an alert.
Stop a rollout that is in progress or rollback for a deployment that has completed 

#### More detailed Upcoming deployments (Next iteration)

An upcoming deployment should be selected by the following order:

1. If there is a running deployment job, the deployment job is selected.
1. If there is a scheduled deployment job (i.e. [`when: delayed`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#when)), the deployment job is selected.
1. If there is a manual deployment job (i.e. [`when: manual`](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/#when)), the deployment job is selected.
1. If there are no relevant deployment jobs, it shows empty.

### Breakdown

- ~frontend to display the badges (this will already show the statuses that are currently provided by the BE) behind a ~"feature flag" (type `development`)
- ~backend to provide the additional statuses

### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behaviour consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

### What is the type of buyer?

Loop in the most relevant PM and Product Designer from that Group to provide strategic support to help align the Group's broader plan and vision, as well as to avoid UX and technical debt. https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/#cross-stage-features -->

title: Allow for easier roll back from alerts page
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

> As an SRE, I want to take action on alert, so I can resolve it.

This is a continuation from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/216949 and intended as a first iteration towards making it easier for SRE's to take action on alert.

Currently, an SRE when navigating towards an alerts page is missing context or the ability to easily see and act on deployments for the related environment.

> Today, we don't show which environment is associated with the alert. e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/monitor/tanuki-inc/-/alert_management/105/details doesn't show environment link. Thus, SREs have no idea which environment is having trouble.

title: Add ESLint rule to prevent using v-html
description:
We should add an ESLint rule to prevent usage of `v-html` in the codebase. 

### Why
`v-html` is bad and can lead to XSS attacks
https://vuejs.org/v2/api/#v-html

### Goal
Our aim is to make sure we don't use `v-html` for any new codebase and audit every possible usage of `v-html` being used.

### Fix
Replace `v-html` with `v-safe-html` ([GlSafeHtmlDirective](http://localhost:9001/?path=/story/directives-safe-html-directive--default))

### Implementation Plan

- [x] Add a new rule
- [x] Disable eslint for existing `v-html` usages
- [x] Open a new issue to audit :point_up: (every disabled instance) - https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4273
- [x] Recommend users to use [GlSafeHtmlDirective](http://localhost:9001/?path=/story/directives-safe-html-directive--default)


### Faqs

1. **When should we disable the rule?**

    When you are absolutely sure that the value being passed to `v-html` is never gonna to be user controlled. Involve appsec team whenever you're unsure.

1. **Why don't we just replace existing `v-html` with `v-safe-html`?**

    Adding `v-safe-html` to every instance (~ 200 as we speak) even when not necessary means that it would be passing all those html content through a sanitization library which could impact the performance of our application. So, ideally we should audit them and make a decision.

title: Increase poll interval for the merged/closed merge requests
description:
### Problem to solve

`widget.json` is not the cheapest request and it has a high request rate: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/209268

In order to reduce the request rate, we can consider increasing poll interval for merged/closed merge requests because they aren't intended to be changed very often.

Currently, we polling the info for a merged MR as frequently as for the open ones:

- the first interval is 10s
- next intervals are: the previous interval multiplied by 2
- max interval is 4 minutes

We can reconsider it and poll info for a merged/closed MR every 5 minutes starting from the beginning

title: Implement generic/reusable filter bar for Analytics features
description:
Currently, `Code Review Analytics` and `VSA` already implement the `GlFilteredSearch` component from `gitlab-ui` along with some shared/reusable tokens.

However, both features still use their own components for the filter bar which is closely coupled to the `Vuex` store of the specific feature.

Let's create a shared/reusable filter bar (parent) component that we can easily reuse across our Analytics features.

There's already a rather generic version implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/32961 by @kushalpandya  which is worth looking into to see if it fits our needs or can at least be reused to some extent.

title: Show sum of issue weights in Epic
description:
### Problem to solve

When looking at the list of Epics and Issues in an Epic ([example](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3403)), there's a helpful indication of how many issues and epics are in the epic being displayed.

It would be even better if these indicators included the recursive total weight for all contained issues and epics.

![image](/uploads/960ab7442471992bf4c10c53c0f97d97/image.png)

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)

### User experience goal

The user is able to determine the amount of work contained in an Epic.

### Proposal

Add the sum of weights to the indicators at the top of Epics and Issues. E.g.

![image](/uploads/94feb5fe1c7b10953b0382c4dc82091a/image.png)

### Further details

A "flat" epic (with only issues as children) is easy.

![image](/uploads/3d25a277e7bf3573802cfe19f48f697b/image.png)

And epic containing one of more epics, would need to find the combined weight of all "flat" epics, add this to the weight sum for any top-level issues and display that instead.

![image](/uploads/154b6bed79eada850738ac405e917819/image.png)

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

### Permissions and Security

The sum relies on issues that the current user (logged in or not) is able to see. We need to decide whether we want to show a potentially incorrect number or show nothing at all if any of the weights are missing.

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?

title: Direct asset URL for releases is returning 404 Not Found
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Found while testing https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/37557.

When you create a release with external assets link (for example https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/11775053/releases/assets-links-1), `direct_asset_url` returned is the following:
```
$ curl https://gitlab.com/api/v4/projects/11775053/releases/assets-links-1 | jq | grep direct_asset_url
        "direct_asset_url": "https://gitlab.com/krasio/public-test-yard/-/releases/assets-links-1/binaries/1",
```
When you try to access this URL it returns `404 Found` instead of redirecting to the external URL.

The reason is that we generate this URL using format like `/releases/:tag/:filepath`, while the route defined for asset links downloads is `/releases/:tag/downloads/*filepath`:
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9cda1414a433c841980d2aa8625c89fd15c9fef6/lib/api/entities/releases/link.rb#L20
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9cda1414a433c841980d2aa8625c89fd15c9fef6/config/routes/project.rb#L196

Even if you manually change the URL from `/releases/assets-links-1/binaries/1` to `/releases/assets-links-1/downloads/binaries/1` it's still not working. The reason is that because the way the route is defined (`'downloads/*filepath'`) the leading slash is not included in `params[:filepath]` but in the controller we do `release.links.find_by_filepath!(sanitized_filepath)` so it fails to find the link.

### Steps to reproduce
* Create a release that has an external asset link (using the API)
* Try to access the external asset


### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/krasio/public-test-yard/-/releases

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The direct asset URL returns `404 Not Found`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The direct asset URL should redirect to the external asset, see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/9cda1414a433c841980d2aa8625c89fd15c9fef6/spec/controllers/projects/releases_controller_spec.rb#L212-250 (btw this spec is passing because it is controller spec and is bypassing the routing, so the `filepath` is provided as expected).

### Possible fixes

1. We can update the way we generate `direct_assets_url` to match the route
1. We can update the route to match the currently generated `direct_assets_url`

IN either case we'll have to add the missing leading slash before we try to find the link from the database. I could not find a way how to define the route in away so that it doesn't remove the leading slash from the param.

title: Make code suggestions be aware of multi-line comment context in Diffs
description:
### Problem to solve

When suggesting code edits in a MR, a user needs to manually edit the offset (i.e.: the `:-0+0`). E.g.:

![image](/uploads/528d4e47186523216b2163fecd5dee5d/image.png)

The user experience isn't intuitive because the offset is auto-populated for a single line:

![image](/uploads/d5323ef549225668353f0dae29a2f30a/image.png)

But not for multiple lines:

![image](/uploads/39538647575d4a8b91476ee04cf09735/image.png)

The documentation for [multi-line suggestions](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/discussions/#multi-line-suggestions) isn't linked from the feature (i.e.: there's a link to [Markdown is supported](https://gitlab.com/help/user/markdown) instead).

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

A user should be able to suggest multi-line code changes without resorting to documentation search.

### Proposal

The value of "Commenting on lines" can be taken into consideration when the user clicks "Insert suggestion" to automatically populate the offset.

Using the example above, it would look like `-3+0`:

![image](/uploads/1090340ffd7284e7b265bf474153697e/image.png)

The suggestion feature is only available in the Markdown toolbar and suggestions are only valid for comments that span added and/or unchanged lines. If such a comment spans both the “old” and “new” sides of the file diff, the suggestion feature only “looks” at the “new” side.

### Further details


### Permissions and Security

title: Switching branches in repo tree view navigates backwards
description:
### Summary

Switching branches in the repository files view after having navigated to some arbitrary subfolder will switch the branch, but also navigate you backwards to the original folder that you started that browser tab in.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master in a new browser tab.
1. Click through a sequence of subfolders. For example, `app > channels > application_cable`.
1. Click the dropdown above the file list and select a different branch – any one will do.
1. Watch as the browser navigates you back to the root of the project within the new branch you selected.

The process can also be repeated by starting your browser tab inside a subfolder instead of the project root:

1. Open https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/db/fixtures in a new browser tab.
1. Click through a sequence of subfolders. For example, `.. > .. > doc > api`.
1. Choose a different branch from the dropdown above the file list.
1. Watch as the browser navigates you back to the `gitlab/db/fixtures` folder within the new branch you selected.

### Example Project

Any project on gitlab.com, including Gitlab itself: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Upon switching branches, you are redirected back to the very first repo folder you were in when the browser tab was opened.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Upon switching branches, the repo view should remain in the same repo folder you were in when you switched the branch. If the folder does not exist in this new branch, you should be redirected to the root of the project.

### Relevant information

- Browser – Chrome Version 81.0.4044.138 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- OS – Windows 10 Build 1709

title: Remove link to Cloudflare cert docs from GitLab Pages docs
description:
### Problem to solve

"Cloudflare certificates" docs directly linked from [GitLab Pages' "Getting Started" section](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/pages/) is now not mandatory for everyone who uses GitLab Pages with HTTPS as GitLab equips [Let's Encrypt integration with Pages](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/pages/custom_domains_ssl_tls_certification/lets_encrypt_integration.html) since [12.1, released on 2019-07-22](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/2019/07/22/gitlab-12-1-released/#automatic-https-for-pages-with-lets-encrypt).

So we can safely remove a link to Cloudflare cert docs from Getting Started section of GitLab Pages docs. A link to that page can be added to [the doc for manually adding SSL/TLS certificates to GitLab Pages](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/pages/custom_domains_ssl_tls_certification/index.html#adding-an-ssltls-certificate-to-pages)

title: Clarify what wildcard environment scopes are in the CI/CD Variables settings.
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

Create a UX solution to clarify what "Create wildcard:" means in the **Environment Scope** dropdown when adding or updating a variable in the CI/CD Variables settings. 

From this discussion (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/5313#note_385278944):

> It might add some clarity to add a tooltip or link defining what a wildcard environment scope is in this UI.
>
> ![image](/uploads/e85a0639293f1d4d84b567f4164be6a2/image.png)

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Address the possibility that a user might not know what a [wildcard environment scope](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#scoping-environments-with-specs) is in the context of the Variables table UI.

#### UX Proposal

- On Project settings > CI/CD > Variables, add a help icon `(?)` next to the label `Environment scope`.
- The help icon `(?)` should link to the documentation page for scoping environments with spec
  - https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#scoping-environments-with-specs

| Prototype | 
| ------ | 
| ![environment-scope](/uploads/74e4808caaddc8800e160dc36c99a1f5/environment-scope.png) | 

### Permissions and Security

* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [x] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members

title: Page Update: GitLab Releases to Include .com and self-managed Tags
description:
### Problem to solve

When viewing our GitLab releases page, as a external consumer I can't distinguish which features are available to me as a SaaS versus Self-Managed customer.

This this page is SUPER helpful in enabling an email that sales uses after each release each month as a touch point with customers and prospects. Essentially, we just want to make sure that our customers are aware of what is in the release without 1) inadvertently setting expectations for something they get excited about but won't end up having access to and 2) having to scroll through the blog to find every feature that isn't highlighted as on .com and then having to do a find and delete in the template (worried about the accuracy of manually doing this myself or asking the SALs to do it for their customers). 

### Intended users

- GitLab customers
- GitLab GTM and support team members providing information to GitLab customers

### User experience goal

When reading GitLab releases information for a given release I should be able to quickly understand whether a posted feature is pertinent given that I am a SaaS or Self-Managed customer.


### Proposal

This information is already available from the same release post item structure that [generates the current content](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/lib/tasks/update_gitlab_project_releases_page.rake#L200). We should add a `badge` similar to the one for `category` called `Self Managed Only` which displays on any release highlight item with the `gitlab_com` key set to false.

### Further details

- [File and proposed function to adjust](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/lib/tasks/update_gitlab_project_releases_page.rake#L200)

### Documentation

No Docs update need.

### Links / references
- [Initial MR creating content update process](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/44837/diffs)
- [Initial MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/57417) for updating the previous page

title: [ENG] Increase healthcheck rollout MVC
description:
Currently, EE users can request a "free healthcheck" which puts them in touch with sales if they're on a free EE license and have over 100 users. 
 
Sid would like us to increase the volume of these leads. 
 
@jeromezng found the underlying code that triggers this in [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/208291#note_295737482). 
 
Propsosed solution: 
 
* MVC update: We reduce the required number of employees down to 50 for free EE instances. 
 
A future iteration in a separate test and associated [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/232644) will be to: 
* We add the "free healthcheck" to CE instances, we need to determine what number of employees is appropriate for this initial CE rollout.

title: Add unique users using paid SAML features to usage ping (Access Paid GMAU)
description:
## Overview
We'd like to track Manage:Access usage across free and paid instances in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/224102. 

We'd also like to have similar instrumentation that only targets paid features to help us understand adoption.

## Proposal
* Track unique users logging in with SAML SSO for Groups (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/saml_sso/#saml-sso-for-gitlabcom-groups-premium) by adding a single aggregate count of distinct users to usage ping.

title: Deleting deploy keys does not inform the user if in use
description:
### Release Notes

In this release, we have added an additional safety measure to warn users that a deploy key is in use before deleting the key. This will help prevent accidentally breaking workflows of that project.  

<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

Follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/30769#note_384759901

Whenever a deploy key is about to be deleted, if that deploy key is currently assigned to a protected branch: deleting this key may disable users to do their CI/CD operations which involved accessing their protected branch.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

Users should be notified of the fact that they might be invalidating CI configurations when deleting a deploy key.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

When deleting a deploy key we should update the modal that is summoned up with a new [GlModal](https://design.gitlab.com/components/modals) and give it the following copy:

- Title: Do you want to delete this deploy key?
- Body: `Are you sure you want to delete this deploy key? If anything is still using this key, it will stop working.`
- Actions:

title: Test zip object storage on docs.gitlab.com and percentage rollout
description:
### Problem to solve In evaluation of the new object storage architecture we want to be able to confirm performance of serving Pages files. We need to use a scale/example with a large archive and lots of files. docs.gitlab.com is a great use case to validate performance # If anything goes wrong Currently, feature is enabled for docs.gitlab.com and for small percentage of user projects. It's been enabled for docs.gitlab.com, so most likely there will be no problem with it. So most likely you'll need to just disable feature for user projects: ``` /chatops run feature set pages_artifacts_archive 0 --actors ``` To disable the feature for everyone: ``` /chatops run feature set pages_artifacts_archive false ``` **Note that it may take a few minutes for changes to take effect because pages daemon caches some data** ## Possible _expected_ problems * Pages daemon consuming too much memory Pages daemon caches list of all files in of web-sites served in memory. In this case, it may be required to restart pages daemon as well after disabling feature flag. * Users complain about range-requests not working This is expected because new architecture does not support them yet. It may be required to rollback the feature. ### Proposal - [x] Test [feature flag](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/238986) on a personal project with and without custom domain to make sure paths are handled properly. (tested on https://vshushlin.gitlab.io/pages-zip2/) - [x] Notify people in slack that we're enabling this feature for docs.gitlab.com - [x] Enable [feature flag](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/238986) for docs.gitlab.com during a less busy time for a few hours a few days in the row - [x] Cross-link chatops message to #docs channel in slack(see https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C16HYA2P5/p1601299492027300?thread_ts=1601298644.026500&cid=C16HYA2P5) - [x] Visualize timings for docs.gitlab.com in https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana and see difference - [x] Enable it for longer time if now problems discovered - [x] Record any discovered problems - [x] If test is successful, leave feature flag enabled. - [x] Get in touch with @davis_townsend to that validate costs for the zip architecture are acceptable ### Testing schedule Please note the following during tests: - Resources loading times, especially anything you would consider slow - Files load correctly e.g. js, css - Report any issues to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231459 - Keep an eye on any metrics/dashboards like Google analytics (if any). Attach any screenshots you consider relevant. | Time frame | Chatops message | Relevant logs | Notes | | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ | | 2020-09-29 1:00 - 2:00 UTC | [slack message](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1601341218185800)(internal)| - [duration_ms](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/f3db66831c03cc997ce8b26c968d919a) graph
- [Logs for docs.gitlab.com](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/2eb90fd03187a9401db58a55f2c35abb)
- [Grafana pages dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-pages-main/web-pages-overview?orgId=1&from=1601339400000&to=1601345700000)
- [Current object storage metrics](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/explore?orgId=1&left=%5B%222020-09-29%2010:30:00%22,%22now%22,%22Global%22,%7B%22expr%22:%22rate(gitlab_pages_object_storage_backend_requests_total%5Cn%5Cn%5Cn%5B1m%5D)%22%7D,%7B%22mode%22:%22Metrics%22%7D,%7B%22ui%22:%5Btrue,true,true,%22none%22%5D%7D%5D&right=%5B%222020-09-29%2010:30:00%22,%22now%22,%22Global%22,%7B%22expr%22:%22gitlab_pages_object_storage_backend_requests_duration%22%7D,%7B%22mode%22:%22Metrics%22%7D,%7B%22ui%22:%5Btrue,true,true,%22none%22%5D%7D%5D) | | | 2020-09-29 7:00 - 8:00 UTC | [slack message](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1601363020194500)(internal) | [Logs](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/4de61a8533a6b781f7ad794968253a56) | nothing major to note, the docs seem to load quite fast | | 2020-09-29 9:00 - 15:00 UTC | [slack message](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1601370153195600)(internal) | | | | 2020-09-30 1:00 - 2020-10-01 1:00 UTC | [slack message](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1601428004216700)| [web-pages dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-pages-main/web-pages-overview?orgId=1&from=1601425800000&to=1601514600000) | | ### Results On test project: on https://vshushlin.gitlab.io/pages-zip2/ and https://vshushlin.gitlab.io/pages-direct/. It's 183ms vs 142ms. Which 40ms increase = 2x20ms and 20 ms RTT to object storage, and we make 2 requests ATM. #### 2020-09-29 1:00 - 2:04 UTC ```sh $ curl -w %{time_connect}:%{time_starttransfer}:%{time_total} https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/README.html 0.208602:0.910168:2.119106 $ curl -w %{time_connect}:%{time_starttransfer}:%{time_total} https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/README.html 3 0.207980:0.904338:2.0835390.000000:0.000000:0.000077 ``` Biggest spike saw in accessing https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/labels.html taking 46,815ms [log entry](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/kibana#/discover/doc/AWRaEscWMdvjVyaYlI-L/pubsub-pages-inf-gprd-000513?id=cfuC13QBh6S0rOAj7bbO). Actually there were a bunch of resources that took longer to load while the feature flag propagation was happening https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/3b642bee543d947df7dd2f80f80e6ee0. #### 2020-09-29 7:00 - 8:14 UTC

Before enabling: ``` ./test-pages-os.sh 0.207729:0.645539:0.849247:1.465081__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000070__ 0.207871:0.645818:0.850220:2.079635__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000063__ 0.207608:0.641499:0.846385:1.670683__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000056__ 0.209177:0.643324:0.847803:2.069051__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000066__ 0.207681:0.646332:0.850879:1.887908__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000080__ 0.207619:0.641780:0.846753:1.674306__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000067__ 0.207567:0.644922:0.849780:1.468063__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000069__ ``` After enabling: ``` ./test-pages-os.sh 0.229817:0.727528:1.010769:1.693572__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000065__ 0.220274:0.731612:1.011359:4.599365__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000080__ 0.214940:0.675841:1.050447:2.017639__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000071__ 0.234498:0.678447:0.991161:4.253598__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000049__ 0.222887:0.722696:1.019366:3.458643__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000053__ 0.213464:0.664025:0.948159:2.449855__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000054__ 0.220699:0.704413:1.185384:3.641204__0.000000:0.000000:0.000000:0.000046__ ```
### Percentage rollout **NOTE**: Rollout issue moved to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/production/-/issues/2808 **Note that this feature can be used only by about 10% of the project, so 5% rollout is actually just 0.5%, 50% is just 5%** ``` /chatops run feature set pages_artifacts_archive 5 --actors ``` * [x] Increase rollout to 5% - https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C101F3796/p1602129978067900 * [-] Increase rollout to 25% * [-] Increase rollout to 40% * [-] Increase rollout to 75% * [-] Increase rollout to 100% ### Monitoring * Grafana dashboards: * https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/pages-main/pages-overview?orgId=1 (no visible changes after 5% enabling) * https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/web-pages-main/web-pages-overview?orgId=1 (no visible changes after 5% enabling) * [Profiler](https://console.cloud.google.com/profiler;timespan=12h/gitlab-pages;type=HEAP/inuse_space?project=gitlab-production) * If you switch to "Heap" you'll see 30% chunk of `(*zipArchive).readArchive` - it shows memory used to store cached index of all files served by pages with enabled zip serving. * It didn't change much after enabling feature to 5%, most likely because docs.gitlab.com is huge and takes most of this space, and 5% other projects don't make a difference * [cached entries](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=1h&g0.expr=gitlab_pages_zip_archive_entries_cached&g0.tab=0) * File entries cached. E.g. If we cache 3 zip archives with 100 files each, this metric should be 300. After 5% rollout this metric grow on one of the servers, but memory usage doesn't. Most likey we don't decrease this metric properly. * [cached zip archives](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=1h&g0.expr=gitlab_pages_zip_cached_archives&g0.tab=0) * basically number of projects which recently were served by zip architecture and cached(for 1 minute). Started to grow after 5% rollout. We think that gradual increase can be explained by the usual increase of pages users over the time of day. More people use pages - more projects stay in cache. * [cache hits/misses](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=1h&g0.expr=gitlab_pages_zip_cache_requests&g0.tab=1) * [open archives count](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=24h&g0.expr=increase(gitlab_pages_zip_opened%5B5m%5D)&g0.tab=0) * same as cached_zip_archives, but without cache. So this counts individual project accessed regardless of cache. Jumped after 5% rollout and stayed at almost the same level, which is expected. * [vfs operations total ZIP vs Local](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=6h&g0.stacked=1&g0.expr=sum(increase(gitlab_pages_vfs_operations_total%5B5m%5D))%20by%20(vfs_name)&g0.tab=0) * show disk operations performed on ZIP vfs(object storage) vs local disk. Didn't change much with 5% rollout, majority of all operations is still docs.gitlab.com * [vfs file open ZIP vs local](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=6h&g0.stacked=1&g0.expr=sum(increase(gitlab_pages_vfs_operations_total%7Boperation%3D%22Open%22%7D%5B5m%5D))%20by%20(vfs_name%2C%20operation)&g0.tab=0) * same as above, but only for open file operations * [rate of opening new ZIP archives](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=1h&g0.stacked=1&g0.expr=increase(gitlab_pages_zip_opened%5B5m%5D)&g0.tab=0) * number of zip archives opened in 5 min, jumped after 5% rollout * [currently allocated memory in Go process](https://prometheus-app.gprd.gitlab.net/graph?g0.range_input=24h&g0.stacked=1&g0.expr=go_memstats_alloc_bytes%7Binstance%3D~%22web-pages-.*%22%7D&g0.tab=0) * didn't change after 5% rollout

title: Security Scanner Alert is showing backend constant value instead of translated name for scanner
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

The alert that shows not-enabled scanners on the project-level security dashboard contains a enum value (`COVERAGE_FUZZING`) instead of a human readable, translatable string:

![Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.55.14_pm](/uploads/536ef5ee653a4443539fbe6a982d0bd9/Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.55.14_pm.png)


### Steps to reproduce

When logged in navigate to a [project's security dashboard](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/security/dashboard). The alert gets displayed on top of the vulnerability list.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/security/dashboard

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The alert contains `COVERAGE_FUZZING`.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

It should display `Coverage Fuzzing` and be translatable.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

| current | expected |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.55.14_pm](/uploads/536ef5ee653a4443539fbe6a982d0bd9/Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.55.14_pm.png) |![Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.58.08_pm](/uploads/0122aa06cea7e9bc8bab2e0de1a3dffa/Screen_Shot_2020-07-24_at_6.58.08_pm.png) |

title: Allow users to gain more context about an epic within the epic board
description:
### 2021-05-18

For this issue to be completed, the **Ancestors** component needs to be added to the epic board sidebar.


### Problem to solve
> When facilitating planning at scale across many teams or groups within my organization, I want a high level view of how my epics are moving through a workflow, so that I can track and report on the progress of features and initiatives.

How might we allow users to view more context and quickly edit an individual epic within their board?

### User experience goal

Users can quickly learn more about an epic in their board and change values like `due date` etc.

### Proposal

Implement a sidebar similar to the issue sidebar on issue boards for MVC. See the design tab for all iterations and ideation.

| Bare MVC iteration | More fleshed out iteration |
| ------ | ------ |
|![Iteration_1_epic_board_sidebar](/uploads/7488b7e52b58706457170cd86b656d70/Iteration_1_epic_board_sidebar.png)| ![Iteration_2_b](/uploads/3ef8229c05e956986290fd7f7280ec1e/Iteration_2_b.png) |


**Figma:** https://www.figma.com/file/BGUo9MG09v2ZlQjnPynALr/231401-Allow-users-to-gain-more-context-about-an-epic-within-the-epic-board?node-id=1%3A45039

##### Epic sidebar drawer, including:
- 🟡 Iteration 1: Ability to open and close "Epic details" drawer
   - Stretch styling: Enlarge header/title to `ui/h2/04 base`. This was intended but never included in the component I believe.
   - Stretch styling: Change background of all these drawers to `$gray-10`
   - Stretch styling: I reduced the width of the drawer here to `288 px` to display content, esp dropdowns, without a bunch of added width. :thinking: Maybe we can play with this a bit @fguibert 
   - Stretch styling: `Edit` buttons should be tertiary. I placed the `12px` instead of `16px` from top of the div here to account for the slight alignment wonkiness when using these buttons inline with text.

- 🟡 Iteration 1: Epic title (wraps to next line if long)
      - Stretch styling: Allow editing (since the awesome Florie already did this). Increase text box height on `Edit` to `64px` for all title editing since most epic and especially issue titles are quite long.
- 🟡 Iteration 1: Identifier (this is part of title :white_check_mark: ) 
- 🟡 Iteration 1: Start date 
      - Stretch styling: The selected date type (the option that is selected, for example `Inherited: #### - ####` should be `$gray-900` similar to other sidebar items with a selected value
- 🟡 Iteration 1: Due date
      - Stretch styling: The selected date type (the option that is selected, for example `Inherited: #### - ####` should be `$gray-900` similar to other sidebar items with a selected value
- 🟡 Iteration 1: Labels 
- 🟡 Iteration 1 or 2: Confidentiality 
      - Stretch styling: Move this under `Labels` and above `Ancestors` in all sidebar views
- 🟡 Iteration 1 or 2: Ancestors 
- 🟡 Iteration 1 or 2: Toggle to turn notifications on and off
- 🟡 Iteration 1 or 2: Add a to do & remove a to do
- 🟡 Iteration 3: Add participants to issue and epic sidebars in board cc @fguibert @cdybenko 
- The selected epic has a active/focus state similar to the current issue board 

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

We could track how often users are clicking into an epic to view more information or edit values.

title: Update Severity counts to match applied filters
description:
### Problem to solve

The current Security Dashboards display tiles for each severity level with a count of the number of vulnerabilities with that severity. However, the count is both static (does not update as you filter the vulnerability list) and does not count vulnerabilities with a `Dismissed` or `Resolved` state. This is confusing as the counts at the top almost never match what you see in the vulnerability list. 

### Intended users

* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-

### Proposal

The counts in the severity "tiles" at the top should always match the number of vulnerabilities displayed of the same severity in the vulnerability list. When a filter (Status, Scanner, Severity, etc.) is applied, the counts should update along with the vulnerabilities displayed in the list.

### Further details

This behavior should apply to the Project, Group, and Instance Security Dashboards

### Documentation

Probably not needed as https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/security_dashboard/ already shows the tiles.

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### Implementation

Pass [the filters](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/first_class_project_security_dashboard.vue#L68) in `first_class_project_security_dashboard.vue` to the [`severity-count` component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/first_class_project_security_dashboard.vue#L108) and manipulate the data to be used in the [`severity-count` GraphQL query](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/vulnerability_count_list.vue#L28) in `vulnerability_count_list.vue`

title: Update common for Static Analysis Group analyzer projects
description:
[common](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common) recently released a new version with [breaking changes](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common/-/merge_requests/105#note_384256750). We need to work through the following MRs to update common for the Static Analysis analyzers:

- [ ] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/brakeman/-/merge_requests/31
- [ ] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bandit/-/merge_requests/38
- [ ] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/eslint/-/merge_requests/38
- [ ] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/flawfinder/-/merge_requests/28
- [ ] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gosec/-/merge_requests/51

title: Create a left sidebar nav item for Epic Boards under Epics
description: ### Problem to solve **Parker:** "When monitoring a team's work in flight, I need to be able to easily review and digest the current progress so that I can confidently report to stakeholders and leadership.” > When facilitating planning at scale across many teams or groups within my organization, I want a high level view of how my epics are moving through a workflow, so that I can track and report on the progress of features and initiatives. This issue is scoped as a portion of the parent epic to [create epic boards](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2864). The scope of this issue is to resolve the following job to be done: How might we allow users to access their epic boards so that they can plan work items at a higher level? ### User experience goal Boards are easily discoverable. ### Proposal For MVC, we will start small and give boards a single nav item that behavior similar to issue boards. - Add a `Boards` option under the `Epics` navigation item. This brings the user to their epic boards. ### Documentation ### Availability & Testing ### What does success look like, and how can we measure that? See how often users visit this item vs create an maintain an epic board.

title: Allow users to edit and manage an existing epic board
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

> When facilitating planning at scale across many teams or groups within my organization, I want a high level view of how my epics are moving through a workflow, so that I can track and report on the progress of features and initiatives.

How might we allow users to edit a board they have already created?

### User experience goal

A user can craft a smartly titled board that is scoped in a way that allows them to focus on only the epics they care about. 


### Proposal

For MVC, we can stay consistent with the current experience within Issue Boards.

![Editing_an_existing_board](/uploads/afb599b5353d17e824383200b6e04271/Creating_a_new_board_modal_1.png)

**Figma:** https://www.figma.com/file/epYXyMqBv0LdJ5F2coAMTf/and-2864-Program-boards?node-id=128%3A24772


#### Editing a board
- Clicking `Edit board` triggers a edit board modal consistent with the issue board experience.
- Users can:
   - Name their board
   - Hide labels from the board 
   - Hide the open list 
   - Hide the closed list
   - Config label filtering for the board 


### Permissions and Security

<!-- What permissions are required to perform the described actions? Are they consistent with the existing permissions as documented for users, groups, and projects as appropriate? Is the proposed behavior consistent between the UI, API, and other access methods (e.g. email replies)?
Consider adding checkboxes and expectations of users with certain levels of membership https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html
* [ ] Add expected impact to members with no access (0)
* [ ] Add expected impact to Guest (10) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Developer (30) members 
* [ ] Add expected impact to Maintainer (40) members
* [ ] Add expected impact to Owner (50) members -->

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

We should measure how often users are hiding lists and labels, as well as scope their boards, so that we may give better defaults in the future.

title: Add code coverage data to GraphQL API
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Problem to solve

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a frontend engineer at GitLab I want the Code coverage reporting data available through GraphQL so I can have flexible access to it in order to iterate on the [code coverage analytics features](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2838) without requiring small backend changes each iteration.

### Intended users

Frontend Engineers at GitLab

### User experience goal
Flexible access to the Code Coverage data for groups and projects over time in order to enable the features outlined in https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2838. 


### Proposal
We should add our code coverage data from `daily_build_group_report_results` into our GraphQL api. 

### Further details
The data is stored in a `jsonb` column inside of the postgres database. It is unclear how writing a GraphQL resolver for this strongly structured json data should work. There's a github issue here: https://github.com/rmosolgo/graphql-ruby/issues/474 that potentially has a solution but investigation is required to figure out if that applies in our case.

title: Update Security Configuration page to link to SAST Configuration UI
description:
This issue tracks the work to link to the [SAST Configuration UI](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830) page from the Security Configuration page.

This work **must** be carried out under the `sast_configuration_ui` feature flag, so that it is available at the same time the SAST Configuration UI page is [enabled](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/231357).

See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/228830#note_384677784 for an on-going discussion about exactly how this page should change visually (if at all).

## Implementation plan

- [ ] Add `configuration_path` property to each of the `features` in [`ee/app/presenters/projects/security/configuration_presenter.rb`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/ee/app/presenters/projects/security/configuration_presenter.rb#L81) (See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/227575#note_378452790 for some context). For all features _except_ SAST, this property would likely just be nil.
- [ ] Update the [configuration table](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_configuration/components/app.vue#L172-187) to link to the given feature's `configuration_ui`, _if it exists_ on the `feature`.
- [ ] For %13.3, the requirement that the project must have a `.gitlab-ci.yml` before a user can create a SAST merge request has been lifted. See this [code TODO](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v13.2.0-rc44-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_configuration/components/app.vue#L122-127).
